metadata.title: Rational and Irrational Numbers
metadata.subject: Mathematics
metadata.description: Understanding rational numbers, irrational numbers, and their representation on the number line.

preAssessment.question: Which of these is a rational number?
A decimal that terminates is always:
Between any two rational numbers there are:
If p is an integer and q is a non-zero integer, then p/q is:

concepts.title: Rational Numbers
concepts.content: A rational number is any number that can be written in the form p/q where p and q are integers and q ‚â† 0. Integers, terminating decimals and recurring decimals are all rational numbers.
concepts.funFact: The word rational comes from the word ratio.

concepts.title: Irrational Numbers
concepts.content: Irrational numbers cannot be written as p/q. Their decimal representation is non-terminating and non-recurring.

keyPoints.text: ‚àön is irrational if n is not a perfect square.
Irrational decimals never repeat in a fixed pattern.

concepts.funFact: œÄ has been computed to trillions of decimal places.

concepts.title: Number Line Representation
concepts.content: Both rational and irrational numbers can be represented on a number line. Rational numbers are exact points from fractions/decimals; irrational numbers are located using geometric construction or decimal approximation.

keyPoints.text: Between any two real numbers there are infinitely many rational and irrational numbers.
Number line gives visual ordering of numbers.

concepts.funFact: The real number line has no gaps.

Between 2/3 and 3/4, how many rational numbers exist?

interactiveElement.title: Build the Formula!

data.explanation: A square has 4 equal sides. Its perimeter is 4 times the length of one side.

longAnswers.question: Between 2/3 and 3/4, how many rational numbers exist?
longAnswers.modelAnswer: There are infinitely many rational numbers between 2/3 and 3/4. To show this, write equivalent fractions: 2/3 = 16/24 and 3/4 = 18/24. The fraction 17/24 lies between them. Again between 16/24 and 17/24, we can find more fractions, and this process can continue without end.
keyPoints: Infinitely many rationals exist between two distinct rationals.
2/3 and 3/4 can be written as 16/24 and 18/24.
17/24 is one rational number between them.
Further subdivision gives endlessly more numbers.

longAnswers.question: Define a rational number with examples.
longAnswers.modelAnswer: A rational number is any number that can be written as p/q where p and q are integers and q ‚â† 0. Such numbers include integers, fractions, terminating decimals, and recurring decimals. Examples are -3, 5/8, 0.75, and 0.222‚Ä¶. Hence all these belong to the set of rational numbers.
keyPoints: Form: p/q with integers and non-zero denominator.
Terminating and recurring decimals are rational.

longAnswers.question: What is an irrational number? Give examples.
longAnswers.modelAnswer: An irrational number cannot be expressed as p/q with integers p and q (q ‚â† 0). Its decimal expansion is non-terminating and non-recurring. Examples include ‚àö2, ‚àö3, and œÄ. So irrational numbers continue endlessly without repeating a fixed pattern.
keyPoints: Cannot be written in p/q form.
No repeating pattern appears in digits.

longAnswers.question: How can ‚àö2 be represented on the number line?
longAnswers.modelAnswer: To represent ‚àö2 on a number line, first mark O at 0 and A at 1 unit. At A, draw AB perpendicular to OA with length 1 unit and join OB. By Pythagoras, OB = ‚àö2. With O as center and OB as radius, cut the number line at P; point P represents ‚àö2.
keyPoints: Transfer OB onto number line to locate ‚àö2.
